unnormalised: My first memory of Indian Railways is etched in my mind like a perfectly brewed cup of chai – comforting, chaotic, and utterly unforgettable. It was 2005, and I was barely 6, clutching my mother's saree as we navigated the bustling platforms of Delhi Jn. The air thrummed with announcements, the rhythmic clatter of luggage wheels, and the tantalizing aroma of samosas frying at a nearby stall. Our destination? Varanasi, a spiritual journey we were undertaking during the auspicious month of Kartik. I remember being awestruck by the sheer size of the train, the "Shiv Ganga Express", a metal behemoth stretching seemingly into infinity.

It was two thousand and five, and I was barely six, clutching my mother's saree as we navigated the bustling platforms of Delhi Junction. The air thrummed with announcements, the rhythmic clatter of luggage wheels, and the tantalizing aroma of samosas frying at a nearby stall. Our destination? Varanasi, a spiritual journey we were undertaking during the auspicious month of Kartik. I remember being awestruck by the sheer size of the train, the "Shiv Ganga Express", a metal behemoth stretching seemingly into infinity.

unnormalised: Finding our seats, 35 and 36 in coach S2, was an adventure in itself. We squeezed past families picnicking on the floor, vendors hawking everything from plastic toys to religious trinkets, and a veritable obstacle course of luggage. Finally, nestled by the window, I gazed out as the train lurched into motion, leaving behind the familiar cityscape of Delhi. The world outside transformed into a blur of green fields, quaint villages, and the occasional glimpse of a shimmering river.

unnormalised: The journey itself was a microcosm of India. A boisterous group of college students filled the carriage with laughter and song. An elderly gentleman regaled us with stories of his travels, highlighting the best places to eat along the route. A family shared their homemade laddoos, sweetening our already memorable experience. Each interaction, each shared smile, painted a vibrant portrait of the country's diversity and warmth. At one point the train was delayed by 2 hrs because of maintenance work on the line near Kanpur.

unnormalised: Mealtimes were a highlight. The pantry car served up steaming plates of dal-chawal, a staple comfort food that tasted infinitely better on the move. The rhythmic clickety-clack of the wheels became the soundtrack to our culinary adventures. Of course, no train journey is complete without the ubiquitous chai, dispensed in small, earthen cups that offered a moment of blissful warmth against the cool night air. Each cup cost Rs. 10.

unnormalised: As we approached Varanasi, the atmosphere shifted. A sense of anticipation filled the air, a shared understanding of the spiritual significance of our destination. The ghats along the Ganges came into view, bathed in the soft glow of the rising sun. It was a sight that transcended words, a moment of profound peace and tranquility. We reached Varanasi at approximately 6:30 AM, a delay of 30 minutes.

unnormalised: That journey, though years ago, remains a cherished memory. It wasn't just about reaching a destination; it was about the experiences along the way, the connections forged, and the indelible mark left by the Indian Railways. It's a reminder that sometimes, the journey itself is the most beautiful destination of all, especially when measured in kilometers and cups of chai.
